The steps are:  define the SOF and M&S requirements that are in excess of the VMap 3 Specification; analyze the existing production capability of the Army topographic units; identify source imagery for capture of the aditional features to VMap 3; defining a case study to prove the plan in Phase 2 of the effort.

title: C4I Distributed Performance Simulation Environment
abstract: Computing and communications requirements to support modern C4I systems have undergone considerable expansion in the last decade. Requirements for C4I interoperability between the services, along with recent developments in C4I doctrine (such as C4I for the Warrior) will require far more sophisticated, more complex, and more heterogeneous computing and communications technology. Effective design and optimization of such complex systems to meet C4I performance requirements poses a significant challenge and is of special interest to USAF organizations such as SSC/ENEB and ESC/XR.  Event-driven performance simulation provides detailed, quantitative evaluation beginning early in the development life cycle. Performance simulation examines the ability of the computing and communications hardware to support computational loading, message traffic, data latency, and other mission performance requirements.  OTI proposes the development of a C4I Distributed Performance Simulation Environment (C4I-DPSE) that will enable C4I system architects to fully exploit simulation as a cost-effective tool for predicting the performance of C4I systems.  C4I-DPSE will be an innovative, state-of-the-art environment for simulating high-performance, distributed computer systems on distributed/parallel computing systems.  OTI's proposed simulation environment will employ optimistic distributed simulation techniques such as Time Warp, as well as other innovative approaches to distributed computing.

title: Advanced Fiber Winding and Design Techniques
abstract: High accuracy angular measurements have been accomplished with fiber gyros having thermally compensated coils wound with PM fiber. When these types of coils are wound in small diameters, higher bending stresses, a greater number of fiber cross-overs, and reduced rotation sensitivity combine to degrade gyro perforamnce through increased bending losses and polarization crosstalk. These cause increased noise and bias uncertainty. Our proposal presents innovative solutions to these problems. We intend to demonstrate a tension insensitive, thermally compensated winding approach. In Phase I, we will utilize our proposed innovations to design and fabricate a number of ultra-miniature fiber sensing coils (OD

title: Nove Electro-Optic Polymers for In-Line Fiber Photonic Devices
Partitioned Optoelectronic Output Interface for Page-oriented Parallel Optical Memory
Hazardous Substance Detection Using Long Wave Infrared Imaging Spectrometer with Uncooled Optics
abstract: A novel design approach is proposed that will allow operating a longwave infrared imaging spectrometer sensor with uncooled opto- mechanical components. This proposal is for the technology demonstration and design validation investigation. The concept is based on earlier work at NASA in remote sensing and in IR imaging spectroscopy, and the proposed investigation will capitalize on a JPL investment of $200,000 in labor and developmental hardware. OKSI, and JPD will jointly develop a demonstrate the first functional, room-temperature-optics, thermal-infrared imaging spectrometer for environmental remote sensing. The proposed development will be bolstered by two concurrent OKSI collaborations that will supplement the TRP/SBIR resources at no direct cost of the program. 1) The Institute of Environmental Management, at the University of Oklahoma will provide overall guidance in relation to hazardous materials identification methods and data processing, site selection and field testing of the sensor. Preliminary analysis indicates that remote sensing using thermal infrared imaging spectroscopy is an effective technology for the detection and identification of various hazardous sustances controlled under the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendment, and illicuit drugs and chemical weapons manufacturing facilities. 2) Under the Visiting Investigator Program, OKSI and NASA Stennis Space Center will jointly conduct market/technology and end-user requirements/commercialization analyses. A major dual-use aspect of the technology relates to hyperspectral automated target recognition, and to mapping and geographical information systems. Anticipated Benefits: Imaging spectroscopy applications are growing at an explosive rate. The proposed technology will lead to the establishment of the first commercial service providing imaging spectroscopy in the thermal infrared. Applications include environmental monitoring (superfund site monitoring, rapid response for monitoring accidental spills and releases), law enforcement (search for illicit drugs production facilities), and geological, soil and plant studies.

title: Array Interferometer for Real-Time IR Sensing
abstract: Current FT-IR spectrometers are based upon the original Michelson design containing a moving mirror, which was first proposed nearly 70 years ago. While spectrometers based on this principle have been very useful, development of a new generation of spectrometers with no moving parts would bring major advances for numerous sensing applications. It could enable real-time measurement, reduced positional uncertainties, reduced spectrometer size, and extended wavelength range. This Phase I project will experimentally test the feasibility of an entirely new type of FT-IR spectrometer. The optical arrangement is designed to produce and detect interferograms in the spatial domain using passive components and a 2-dimensional detector array. Particularly promising features of this array interferometer include high light throughput, a full spectrum time response limited only by the detector, and potential for miniaturization. In Phase I, a laboratory-scale interferometer will be built and tested. The experimental effort will provide information on the apparatus function, resolving power, sensitivity and optical abberations. If the effort is successful, a complete spectrometer system will be developed and commercialized in Phases II and III.

title: Predictive Kalman Filter Design for Situation Awareness Under Bandwidth Constaints
agency: Office of the Secretary of Defense

title: High Throughput E-Beam Lithography System
abstract: NOVA Scientific, Inc. proposes to develop an electron-beam lithography system capable of high throughput patterning of full-sized semiconductor wafers with minimum feature size to 0.1 um and below. NOVA's key design element is the use of a novel and robust electron source based upon field emission phenomena that is capable of delivering high current to the resist for fast, reproducible exposures. Since the design concept includes an emitter array that is somewhat larger than the wafer, patterning of the entire wafer in orthogonal directions is accomplished in only a few steps, and the total wafer travel in these steps is limited to less than 100 um. Thus, the combination of high current density and global exposure assures high wafer throughput. In addition, the traditionally poor reliability of field emission cathodes in an e-beam system is obviated by the unique design of the electron source. This design is expected to increase cathode stability and reliability by many orders of magnitude.

title: Microchannel Plate Imaging Neutron Detector
abstract: One highly desired improvement for neutron sensing is an imaging neutron detector with high two-dimensional spatial resolution and a large detector area. At present, achievable real-time neutron imaging detector resolution is only about 1 mm. The innovation proposed is to adapt for neutron imaging the high spatial resolution Microchannel Plate (MCP) detector technology so widely used for detecting charged particles and photons. Here, spatial resolution at the 25 micron level is routinely achieved, over formats as large as 10 x 10 cm(2). Previous attempts to use MCPs in neutron detection schemes employed either a Gd neutron-beta converter coupled to an MCP image intensifier with phosphor screen readout, or a thin Li glass scintillator optically coupled to the MCP, compromising the intrinsic MCP spatial resolution and dynamic range. In sharp contrast, this program proposes the combination of (n,"varies as") capture conversion and multiplication processes within the MCP bulk structure itself, fabricated using a lead glass which includes the isotope 10(B). In combination with a fast electronic readout, this innovation will result in a simple, efficient, rugged and compact imaging neutron detector with 15 to 25 um spatial resolution and high dynamic range.

title: VOC Capture by Organophillic Pillared Montmorillonites
abstract: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are used widely as solvents in   painting (e.g., stripping and coating), drug manufacturing,   cleaning, degreasing, metal fabrication, electronics manufacturing,   and many other industries.  Release of VOCs has caused a hazardous   situation not only to human health but also to the environment,   such as chloroglurocarbons contributing to the depletion of the   ozone in the stratosphere.  Stricter regulations have been   established to control VOC release.  NOXSO Corporation is proposing   to use organophillic pillared montmorillonite (OPM) to capture and   control VOCs.  This is a new application for the OPMs.   Montmorillonite clays have aluminosilicate layers which posses   negative charges due to the substitutions in the crystal lattice.   This charge is countered by cations between the layers.  Layers are   weakly held together by electrostatic charges and can be separated   in water.  This practice allows exchange of the interlayer cations   with other cations in the solution, and results in a permanent   layer separation which allows access between the layers and the   tailoring of the chemical characteristics of the pillared   montmorillonite by choice of the appropriate exchange ions.  Phase   I will investigate the technical feasibility of this novel VOCs   control technology.  If Phase I is successful, Phase II will   evaluate the technology at pilot scale.

title: Dual Use Neutron Beams
abstract: Design concepts for neutron beams will be developed that provide optimum use for Neutron Computer Tomography applied to inspection of jet aircraft engine blades for hydrogen content that could cause embrittlement of the titanium-aluminum alloy.  also, design concepts for neutron beams that could contribute to progress in Neutron Capture Therapy will be developed.  The extent to which the same neutron source cold be used alternately for the dual application will be evaluated.  Anticipated benefits include improved production-mode non-destructive inspection capability for hydrogen distribution in engine fan blades for hydrogen concentration in the range 100-200 ppm.  This will contribute to engine maintenance procedures for USAf aircraft, and will also provide engineers performing design and accident analysis with data to help minimize the risks of aircraft engine failure in flight.  Progress that is made in either the jet engine inspection field or the radiation therapy field should have value both in the military and commercial domains.

title: Small, Efficient, Wide-Band, Low-Noise Antenna Elements
abstract: Broadband, sensitive antenna elements that are significantly smaller than resonant length would be valuable assets for use in arrays, or in interferometers, or individually for diverse applications such as commercial communications service, broadcast reception and military direction finding.  Nevertheless, such an asset has eluded development even though qualified researchers have made many attempts.  In this proposal an approach to achieving this goal is described.  It relies on an innovative configuration of antenna elements, low noise amplifiers, and matching circuitry which circumvents a formerly universal law of electrically small antennas:  that gain-bandwidth product is proportional to effective volume.  Preliminary studies indicate that an antenna of 0.75 meter extent can operate with 90 percent reception efficiency down to 20MHz.  During Phase I, NTL Technologies Inc. and its subcontractor, AIL Systems Inc., will thoroughly analyze the performance of the proposed configuration with respect to reception efficiency, noise power contribution, and dynamic range.  Consideration of transmitting configurations will be deferred until Phase II.

title: Epitaxial Materials for Spatial Light Modulators
abstract: New materials are the most important issue for the improvement of the present spatial light modulators (SLMs) meeting the requirements for future optical information processing.  Ferroelectric oxides are intrinsically fast response materials, and suitable for low voltage operation because of their large electro-optic (E-O) coefficients.  However, these high figure of merit materials have not been utilized for practical SLM applications because of the difficulties in obtaining high quality materials.  Epitaxial vapor phase growth is an alternative approach to fabricating large area single-crystalline films.  In this Phase I, NZ Applied Technologies and Prof. R.A. Chipman of the University of Alabama in Huntsville propose to demonstrate the feasibility of using thin films of BaTio3 and PLZT, with the largest E-O coefficients known, for SLM fabrication.  The optical quality, single-crystalline films will be epitaxially grown by an innovative plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PE-CVD).  The PE-CVD is suited for SLMs due to its large-area, low temperature, high growth rate, and low cost fabrication capabilities.  The basic modulator performance of the proposed materials will be determined by a novel Mueller Matrix Imaging method.  In Phase II, the materials will be optimized, and prototype devices will be produced.

title: Lossless Beam Splitters Based on Rare-Earth Doped Fluoride Films
abstract: Phase I seeks to develop lossless beam splitters in a planar integrated optical waveguide form for optical signal processing. We propose to construct lossless beam splitters based on a planar integrated optical waveguide form for the applications at 1.55 um. The proposed device consists of a beam splitter part and an optical amplification part. The device will be built on Er-doped fluoride glass films deposited by a plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) process. The resulting integrated lossless beam splitters will lower the system cost and simplify the optical signal processing system. Fluoride glasses are inherently superior compared to conventional silicate glasses for the luminescence of rare-earth ions. Fluoride glasses also compatible with large concentration of rare-earth ions. Plasma-enhanced CVD allows the growth of wide variety of materials at very low temperatures. This offers the opportunity to grow high optical quality fluoride glass films. The PECVD is suited for the fluoride glass films due to its large-area, low temperature, high growth rate, and low fabrication cost capabilities. Rare earth doped multicomponent fluoride glasses can be obtained by our innovative single liquid source approach.  The resulted films should be readily adaptable for the fabrication of lossless beam splitters in planar waveguide-forms.

title: Ternary Nitride Semiconductors as Nonlinear Optical Materials
abstract: NZ Applied Technologies proposes to develop plasma-enhanced metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (PE-MOCVD) to create optically clear single crystal films of several unexplored ternary nitride semiconductors to study their nonlinear optical properties, and to use them for frequency doubling of visible and near IR lasers into wavelengths ranging from green to violet. Ternary nitrides appear to be excellent candidates for second harmonic generation (SHG) because they are transparent in the visible and, due to their noncentrosymmetric (rhombohedral) crystal structure, must exhibit birefringence; the latter is a basic requirement for phase-matching. Use of activated nitrogen from a plasma will permit them to be grown with low defect densities, a must for minimizing optical losses when configured as waveguides. The ability to produce these nitrides as waveguides will increase the interaction length between primary and secondary fields, giving significantly higher power conversion efficiency. Phase matching can further be enhanced by applying external fields transverse to the ternary waveguides. Phase I will determine the conditions needed to grow these new ternary nitride films. Grown films will be measured to determine structural, optical, and electrical properties. A simple second harmonic generation (SHG) experiment will be performed. In Phase II, growth conditions will be optimized and functioning SHG devices demonstrated.

title: MOCVD Growth of Epitaxial GaN on Lattice-Matched Substrates
abstract: The III-V nitride semiconductor family affords many unique properties which make these materials attractive candidates for producing electronic and optoelectronic devices. Much progress has been made in epitaxial thin film growth of nitrides using metalorganic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) and molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) during the last decade. These efforts are hindered by the lack of lattice-matched substrates. Most studies have employed sapphire substrates for GaN although there is a large mismatch between these materials. GaN films on sapphire substrates have a great number of threading dislocations which propagate up to the surface. Such highly defective material suffers both from low carrier mobilities and lifetimes. Although low temperature, pulsed laser operation has been achieved, the defects may also act as optical scattering centers, preventing the demonstration of a low threshold CW injection lasers operating at room temperature. Recently, LiAl02 and lithium gallate, substrates with improved lattice matching to GaN, have been developed. In preliminary experiments, GaN grown on LAO by ECR MBE at 800 C, exhibited optically pumped stimulated emission. However, MBE is not suitable for production applications and, in addition, LAO and LGO cannot withstand the high temperatures used in conventional MOCVD. NZ Applied Technologies has achieved promising results for GaN growth at low substrate temperatures using a novel MOCVD-based growth process. This approach can yield high quality GaN on LAO or LGO substrates at substrate temperatures which are compatible with these new materials. This would represent the first successful use of MOCVD with LAO or LGO and would pave the way for their use in a manufacturable process for optoelectronic devices.

title: Single AlGaInP Semiconductor Laser Pumped Widely Tunable Mid-IR Generator
abstract: Mid-infrared laser sources in the range of 2-5 mm have many important applications such as eye-safe detection, trace-gas monitoring, and wind speed/wind shear measurements.  Traditional techniques by optical parametric oscillation (OPO) and dual-laser frequency difference generation require (DFG) high power pump sources and very complex systems.  Fabrication of these systems is costly.  In this program we propose to develop a single diode-laser pumped mid-IR laser system.  The near-IR intermediate output pumped by the 670-nm A1GaInP diode laser mixes with the residual diode laser beam in a quasi-phase matched (QPM) KTA nonlinear crystal and mid-IR signals is generated by intra-cavity QPM-DFG.  The mid-IR output can be tuned over a wide range by merely tuning the near-IR; no temperature or angle tuning of the KTA crystal is needed.  The tunable mid-IR laser system is all-solid-state, simple, low cost, and highly efficient.  Power generation capability are estimated to be hundreds of milliwatt power.|  Benefits:  Success in this Phase I program will identify the promising concept and provide a viable manufacturing route for practical compact mid-IR laser sources.|

title: High Power Ternary Nitride Heterrojunction Transistors
abstract: We propose to develop high temperature heterojunction transistors for millimeter wave applications based on material deposition technology for growing epitaxial thin films of a unique series of ternary nitride alloys.  The final transistor structure will rely on a gallium nitride (GaN) film as the second member of the heterojunction.  Ternary nitrides are excellent candidates for service as transistor bases or channels since they offer a wide range of band gaps which are lower than corresponding binary nitrides (GaN, A1N) while being very closely lattice matched, insuring high gain operation.  Our proposed efforts will utilize plasma-enhanced metalorganic chemical vapor deposition, a technology we have developed for the growth of stoichiometeric binary nitrides.  Deposition of the unique series of nitride alloys will require the substitution of several suitable precursor species in place of triethylgallium, while maintaining a high flow rate of activated nitrogen species.   Phase I studies will determine the best growth conditions by systematically varying the substrate temperature and precursor flow ratios in the gas phase, until the process yields excellent quality wide-gap nitride films.  These films will be structurally characterized by electron microscopy and x-ray diffractometry.  Additional optical and electrical measurements will provide feedback for optimizing the growth. Preliminary MESFET devices will be fabricated and evaluated.  In PHase II, emphasis will be placed on optimization of device performance.

title: Novel Tunable Dielectric Microwave Filters
abstract: The rapid expansion in the use of microwave communications has created a need for dramatically improved microwave devices.  Frequency filters are a key component in the wireless communication and military systems.  Currently available filters are discrete bulky components.   In this program NZ Applied Technologies in collaboration with Las Alamos National Laboratory proposes to develop novel tunable dielectric filters.  This new microwave filter technology holds the promise of significant reduction in size, improvement in performance, and the potential for monolithic integration with GaAs ICs.  Moreover, the electrical tunability of this type of devices is desirable for the wireless communication systems capable of operation across frequency bands and for military microwave systems capable of frequency agility.  This technology forms a base for various advanced microwave devices such as active phase shifters and frequency agile antennas.  The recent advances in complex-oxide thin film processing have opened an unprecedented opportunity to realize the proposed devices.  Our preliminary work has demonstrated the basic performance of frequency resonance and electrical tunability of the proposed devices.  In this Phase I, we will further develop both materials and prototype devices by an innovative plasma-enhanced chemcial vapor deposition (PE-CVD).  The PE-CVD is suitable for high volume and low cost manufacturing.  Anticipated Benefits:  Success in the Phase I effort will provide a viable manufacturing route for advanced microwave filters, which have a huge market potential.  This technology is also a basis for various microwave devices such as tunable delay lines, tunable resonators, parametric amplifiers, and frequency agile phase array antennas.

title: Thin Film Electro-Optic Beam Steering Device
Broadband IR Protective Shutter
Large Area and High Resolution Field Emission Displays
Deposition of Magneto-Optical Thin Films on InP by PE-MOCVD for Waveguide Isolators in Optoelectronic Integrated Circuits
Title missing
Advanced Techniques for Arena Testing & Image Motion Modeling/Reconstruction
Very-high-resolution, Large-field-of-view, Wireless, Color Helmet-mounted Desplay
abstract: This proposal describes a novel technique to fabricate small-size high-resolution active matrix displays and to integrate them into wide angle helmet-mounted-displays.  Conventional thin-film transistors fabricated with amorphous and polysilicon technologies are not capable of supporting such high resolution due to their low carrier mobility.  We propose to replace such low performance amorphous or polysilicon transistors with single crystal transistors on a transparent substrate using a new approach.  Or approach is well suited for mass production and will out-perform the other single crystal approaches in terms of yield-reliability and cost.  A multiple-displays-per-eye approach will be taken to achieve the desired wide field of view.  Wireless communication choices will be examined to select the most power efficient, compact system for the Phase Ii prototype.  LEEP systems which built NASA's first prototype helmet mounted display will be a subcontractor on the project.

title: Passive Tracking for Countermeasure Effectiveness (CMEM/LOLA: Loss
Missing Title
Large Throw, Imbedded Microactuator Drag Reducers
abstract: Control of vortices on the leading edge of an airfoil has the potential to decrease drag and increase lift by decreasing the pressure on the forward facing and upper airfoil surfaces.  A novel microactuator is proposed which allows for arbitrarily large displacements to be achieved.  The actuator is also mechanically robust as compared to "conventional" silicon-based microactuators.  Large arrays of the actuators can be deployed in order to obtain fine control of the boundary layer, without a large weight penalty which is typical of macroscopic systems.  The system will allow for the elimination of fixed stall fences and vortex generators, thereby eliminating the drag which they induce during most flight regimes.  The anticipated effects may be great enough to allow the elimination or the reduction of traditional flight control devices such as rudders and ailerons, when used in a laterally asymmetrical configurations.  The program will accomplish four objectives.  The principal of microactuator controlled vortex generation will be demonstrated in a wind tunnel.  Scale-up and implementation factors will be evaluated.  A simplified microactuator system will be designed and fabricated to demonstrate the feasibility of implementing the novel microactuator.  Finally, preliminary design of a complete system will be performed to prepare for, and help ensure the success of Phase II and Phase III programs.

title: Orbitec Fiber Optic Rotation Mini-Sensor (FORMS)
abstract: Orbital Technologies Corporation (ORBITEC) proposes a miniature optical sensor that will be able to accurately measure angle of rotation. The Fiber Optic Rotation Mini-Sensor (FORMS) will also implement fiber optics in such a manner that the sensor will be EMI immune, and smaller than other currently available rotation sensors. The combination of accuracy, stability, reliability, and durability, along with previously stated advantages, of the proposed sensor will demonstrate its superiority over any other currently available rotation sensor. The anticipated accuracy will rival that of commonly used optical encoders. The technology proposed will allow for implementation of this sensor into any system that currently uses a rotation sensor or has a rotation joint, with little or no impact to joint size. Currently perceived applications include: aircraft control surface positions, aircraft door and panel positions, aircraft and launch vehicle thrust control devices, spacecraft antenna and instrument pointing, rotation control knobs, and many commercial applications in areas of biomedicine and consumer products. Anticipated Benefits: The Fiber Optic Rotation Mini-Sensor (FORMS) will provide a small, light-weight, accurate, EMI-immune, miniature rotation sensor for aircraft control surfaces, thrust vector monitors, control and instrumental knobs, other aircraft/spacecraft applications, and many commercial non-aircraft applications. FORMS could replace any currently used rotation sensor and provide new rotation sensing opportunities that were previously not possible due to size, weight, and environmental restrictions.

title: Cryogenic Hybrid Rocket Engine for Testing High-Energy Propellants
MIRIAD: An Interoperable Framework for Design Rationale
abstract: Reuse of design rationales, while essential to long-term goals of both design rationale capture and software reuse, presents significant challenges to current technology.  Organon Motives, Inc. (OMI) and Knowledge Evolution, Inc. (KEI) propose a system, MIRIAD (Models for Interoperable Rationale, Inference and Alternative Designs), for recording and managing reusable rationale in semantically structured repositories, MIRIAD builds on two ongoing research initiatives, FAMILIAR is a DDARPA/EDCS-funded system for management of design rationale being jointly developed by KEI and OMI.  Ariadne is an OMI-funded framework, partially derived from DARPA-funded Open-RLF technology, for specifying heterogenous semantic model types and managing interoperation among models and related applications, MIRIAD will support codification and reuse of FAMILIAR-generated rationales, alternatives, and trade-offs in representations that are separable from underlying semantics of the system descriptions they annotate.  Ariadne will beused to specify model types and framework for managing semantically related collections of FAMILIAR rationales.  Repositories will interoperate with FAMILIAR inference capabilities, as well as with diverse software engineering environments.  This will enable engineers to access and record rationale throughout a system's development and evolution, and to reuse rationales in a new and even unanticipated design situations.

title: Multisensor Fusion Processing
abstract: In this SBIR effort, ORINCON is proposing application of innovative fusion concepts to a mission of interest.  In particular, we are addressing the JOINT STARS mission that exploits integration of off-board sources such as unmanned serial vehicles (UAVs), airborne warning and control systems (AWACS), and RIVET JOINT. This is one of the goals of the Off-board Augmented Theater Surveillance program at Rome Laboratory.  The innovative fusion concepts we propose to design and develop are:  1) noncooperative target sensor registration (NCTSR) to handle off-board reports/tracks that are biased from truth due to unknown platform and sensor alignment errors; 2) the ability to process time correlated track reports that are sent over to the fusion node from an off-board tracking system; and 3) the development of a Bayesian classification algorithm to exploit parameter attribute and classification clues from various reporting systems.    Each of these designs will be integrated into an existing multiple hypothesis tracking (MHT) algorithm that has been developed at ORINCON over a period of 10 years.  The final integrated MRT design will then undergo preliminary testing against Rome Laboratory-approved test scenarios that are representative of JOINT STARS missions.  Results and recommendations will then be summarized in a final test report.

title: Adaptive Beamforming for a Sonobuoy Planar Array
abstract: Adaptive beamforming can provide significant improvements in the active and  passive performance of sonobuoy arrays.  The algorithm must have the following  properties: robust, rapidly convergent, providing increased low frequency array  gain, providing effective nulling of interference, and be suitable for low cost  implementation in a sonobuoy of limited size and power availability.  ORINCON has  identified several promising approaches to this adaptive beamforming problem.  These will be evaluated in Phase I using broadband dynamic simulation with  realistic interferers, reverberation, and multipath propagation.  Recorded data  will be used if it is available.  The best algorithm in terms of performance and  cost will be selected for implementation in low-cost, miniaturized hardware.  Miniaturized hardware design will be accomplished during the Phase I Option  period to permit early hardware delivery in Phase II.

title: Design and Development of a Coarse-Grained Parallel Desktop Computing System for Enhanced Image Processing
abstract: The use of imagery in military and civilian applications has expanded greatly in  recent years.  This growth has been driven primarily by the digital revolution in  microelectronics, which has provided the signal processing, memory storage, and  communications technology that make the wider use of images possible.  The very  ability to collect large numbers of images in near-real time creates another  challenge - how to scan all the images and find objects of interest.  The result is  a need for high-speed digital signal and image processing systems and large mass  memory storage devices to process, store, and analyze these data.  To meet this  need, ORINCON proposes during Phase I to complete the following tasks: (1) design  of a coarse-grained parallel computer workstation architecture suitable for image  processing and based on commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware, (2) demonstration  of possible 2-D and 3-D visualization techniques for transformed images, (3) design  and documentation of an integrated Operator-Machine Interface (OMI), and (4)  demonstration of a prototype for this image processing workstation.  Phase II  efforts will focus on the implementation of a 20-GFLOPS design capable of  processing at least six different image types in near-real time.

title: Real-Time Hybrid Neural Net Object Recognition System (HNNORS)
abstract: Recognition of minw-like targets using an autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a difficult task due to algorithm complexity and data volume. Presently, much of the video data gathered in the field has to be processed Off-line.  Computer system that can perform billions of floating point operations per second (GFLOPS) are required for on-line processing of 512x512 images.  ORINCON proposes to design a Hybrid Neural Net Object Recognition System (HNNORS) by integrating a high-performance parallel processor architecture with advanced neural net classifiers and a suite of image processing algorithms.  Four tasks will be completed in the Phase I effort: (1) Conduct an extensive investigation into the available high-performance parallel processor architectures based on commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) hardware and then propose a final candidate; (2) Perform rapid prototyping of HNNORS using the Programming and Processing Environment (RIPPEN) algorithm proven successful for underwater scene hardware modules into the parallel a contributions to enhance HNNORS, real-time performance prototype HNNORS on an in-house parallel processor video imagery.  93) Conduct an investigation into the incorporation of available dedicated image processing hardware modules into the parallel architecture and evaluate their potential contributions to enhance HNNOR's real-time performance; and and (4) Demonstrate a architecture using underwater video imagery.

title: An Intelligent Ultrasonic Scanning System for Automatic Circuit Card Fault Detection
abstract: Several nonintrusive methods exist to detect faults, such as delaminations, broken leads, traces, and solder joints, and popcorn cracks on circuit cards and integrated circuits (IC).  Ultrasonic scanning is widely utilized by IC manufacturers for this purpose.  However, these failure analysis systems require skilled engineers to operate them.  ORINCON proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of automatically detecting circuit card and IC faults using ultrasonic scanning.  In Phase I, we will apply signal and image processing techniques for optimum feature extraction and intelligent system techniques to automatically detect features representing faults.  The system will be generalized to allow the user to scan an example good card and subsequently scan a problematic card to detect faults.  This system will be based on two commercial off-the-shelf components:  ORINCON'S RIPPEN signal and image processing software and SONIXs HS 1000 HiSpeed acoustic scanning microscope.  The ORINCON-SONIX team is uniquely qualified to perform this research.  ORINCON possesses extensive experience in similar problems involving rotating machinery fault detection, medical ultrasound, and underwater acoustics.  SONIX is a world leader in the development of ultrasonic inspection systems for integrated circuit failure analysis.  In Phase II, the system will be refined and manufacturing plans will be developed.

title: Radar-Sonar Data Fusion for Enhanced Shallow-Water Surveillance
abstract: Due to the harsh underwater acoustic and surface search radar conditions in  shallow littoral ocean areas, performance in detection, classification, and  tracking of submarine targets is degraded by excessive clutter.  Success against  these targets necessitates data fusion and tracking of multisensor data from  organic and off-board sensors.  Based on ORINCON's Phase I analysis, a detailed  integrated algorithm specification will be developed and demonstrated.  ORINCON  will build on the extensive experience it has gained in multisensor and  multiplatform data fusion to reduce the development cost of a data fusion system  capable of overcoming the inherent difficulties of shallow-water environments.  Our recent involvement with Air Force E-3 multisensor and multiplatform data  fusion will vastly reduce the time to develop the data preprocessing required to  handle nonorganic radar surveillance information.  An integrated algorithm for  utilizing information generated by the shallow-water environment prediction tool  will be designed.  A proof-of-concept demonstration of the environmental  information integration system is proposed as an optional task.

title: VIBRATION ANALYSIS OF ROTATING PLANTS USING ADVANCED SPECTRAL TECHNIQUES AND NUERAL NETS
Advanced Tools for Information Warfare
SHALLOW WATER JOINT SURVEILLANCE DATA FUSION
ENVIRONMENTALLY STABLE EMBEDDED COMPONENTS FOR SEVERE ENVIRONMENT MULTICHIP MODULES
abstract: The objective of Phase I will be to fabricate resistors, capacitors, and inductors using these materials and do some preliminary environmental testing on them. Phase II objective would be to demonstrate repeatable, high quality formation of the buried components that will be based on current multichip module technology and will be fabricated using existing infrastructure of the printed circuit board industry.

title: High Strength Flexible Adhesives for Environmentally Demanding Rigid-Flex Circuitry
abstract: Rigid-flex printed circuits consist of a rigid and flexible electrical laminates sandwiched together to form a composite structure having both rigidity and flexibility. They are attractive for commercial and military high performance applications because size and weight is reduced while reliability is increased. The adhesives utilized in these circuits play a central role in determining the reliability of the rigid-flex circuit. Meeting the thermomechanical stress requirements of military and complex commercial applications is a problem with current adhesives. Several hurdles exist: inadequate bond strengths after thermal cycling, inadequate flexibility where thermal cycling is required, low resistance to decomposition, low dielectric strengths, large Z-axis coefficients of thermal expansion, moisture absorption, low resistance to chemical attack and high costs. This proposal entails the development of new flexible co-polymer adhesives based on newly discovered polyester oligimers which can have higher bond strengths, higher operating and decomposition temperatures, lower coefficients of thermal expansion, and higher flexibility. The adhesives should retain superior properties, even under sever thermal and environmental conditions and should be processable by established processes and equipment. The Phase I objective is to prove the principle of a multifunctional epoxy polyester oligimer co-polymers to bond laminate components of a rigid-flex circuit together. OPTION: $20,008

title: Fabrication and Assembly of High Operating Temperature Circuits
abstract: There is a trend towards an architecture that uses digital data buses to transfer information between control system components.  The hurdle to distributed control architecture is that it moves components from benign into harsh environments.  A major challenge is the need for operation at temperatures well above 125 degrees C.  A consortium of US firms has formed to commercialize Silicon on Insulator (SOI) electronics.  This technology promises devices capable of withstanding elevated temperatures.  The associated high temperature packaging for this technology needs to be developed to implement the emerging distibuted controls.  New circuit board materials and designs able to withstand high tempratures need to be developed.  A basic materials set to address high temperature opertion was demonstrated by Toranaga as part of another SBIR Phase I program.  What is needed is a systematic aproach and fabrication and assembly process methods.  The objective of this Phase I effort will be to refine fabrication processes and to investigate assembly methods for low cost high temperature multilayer circuit fabrication for use in distributed controls.  Two applications will be developed and demonstrated: a smart engine vane actuator operating at 200 degrees C and an automotic Anti-locking Brake System controller operating at 150 to 175 degrees C.  Anticipated Military Benefits/Potential Commercial Applications of the Research or Development:  The weight, reliability and cost savings that are achieved by elimination of cooling systems could be enormous.  It will result in the wide scale use of high temperature electronics in numerous military and commercial distributed control applications.  This technology promises to inexpensively and rapidly yield a system for the fabrication of high temperature circuits.  These new materials and system will increase reliability, reduce processing steps and complexity, and reduce cost over conventional high temperature packages such as cermic MCMs or polymide/glass printed circuit boards.

title: Flat Panel Displays Based on Light-Emitting Electrochemical Cells
Control Systems for Linearized External Modulators
abstract: Ortel proposes to investigate methods of performing closed loop   control of optically linearized modulators for use in externally   modulated analog fiberoptic links.  These links are becoming more   popular at 1550 nm because of lower optical loss at the longer   wavelength, and because of the availability of low-noise   all-optical amplifiers (EDFAs).  Ordinary Mach Zehnder modulators   have poor third-order intermodulation performance.  Optically   linearized modulators overcome this limitation at the expense of   great sensitivity to operating parameters.  In order to achieve the   best possible linearity over the temperature range and lifetime of   the transmitter, it is necessary to perform closed loop control of   the splitting ratio between the RF inputs to the optically   linearized modulator, as well as bias voltage control.  A method is   proposed to perform closed loop minimization of third-order   distortion in these modulators by controlling the RF splitting   ratio.  We also propose to investigate methods of bias voltage   control for minimization of second-order distortion.

title: High-Power 1550 nm InGaAsP MOPA with Simplified Coupling to Single-Mode Fiber
abstract: A high-power cw optical  source at 1550 nm is a key component of an externally modulated optical transmitter for future optical networks.  Due to its high efficiency, reliability, and compact size, an integrated semiconductor MOPA is a promising candidate for achieving high power.  However, it is difficult to couple the MOPA output to single-mode fiber in a reliable, compact package.    We propose a program to develop a high-power 1550 nm InGaAsP integrated MOPA structure with an on-chip mode converter to simplify coupling to a single-mode optical fiber.  In Phase I, we will develop a design for an integrated semiconductor amplifier and mode converter.  The design concept will be demonstrated in a working prototype with single-mode fiber coupled output.  Predicted output power improvements from a fully optimized, integrated MOPA structure will be modeled and analyzed.|  Benefits:  High power optical sources at 1550 nm will improve the dynamic range of externally modulated fiberoptic links used in military applications such as antenna remoting and signal processing.  Commercial cable television systems will benefit from high optical source power which will lead to unrepeatered optical distribution networks.|

title: Active Metal Joining of Thermoplastic Matrix Composites
abstract: Joining of thermoplastic matrix composites to form large panels in strucutrs by fastening, adhesive bonding or resistance induction welding produces joints that can be the "weak link" resulting in failure. A hybrid technique involving a laser beam will be studied in this Phase I effort. The objective of this research is to metallurgically join thermoplastic matrix composites such as PEEK reinforced with AS4, or IM 7/IM 8 fibers using a rapid thermal processing (RTP), active-metal alloy technique. These composites are expected to be used in several modules and components such as fenders, doors, structural panels in automobiles and package housings for the electronics in many commercial and defense systems. The joints produced using these methods are expected to be sound and result in components with high structural intgrity. Destructive tests are proposed in Phase I to evaluate the joint quality and performance. This method would allow for the introduction of intelligent manufacturing systems that could facilitate the rapid production of large sized panels/joints at low costs. In Phase II, further refinement of the processing parameters is expected so that scale up to commercialization would be feasible.

title: Novel Surge Suppression Devices
Dendrimer- Based Oxazoine Derivative Protection Coatings
abstract: This proposal responds to the DOD requirement for a dendrimer-based coating to protect materials from chemical agent contamination and degradation due to environmental and POL (petroleum, oil, lubricant) exposure.  The benefits of such protection include enhanced reliability, improved safety, reduced maintenance costs, and extended service life.  The development of a low energy coating based on the integration of well defined fluorocarbon, oxazoline, and dendrimer technologies is proposed herein as a highly viable approach to overcoming the limitations of existing products. Precise control of dendrimer architecture will permit the formulation of of high performance fluorocarbon coatings with optimal chemical, mechanical, thermal, and rheological properties for DOD applications.  Moreover, the potential advantages of dendrimer coatings over conventional fluoropolymers include water-based application, superior adhesive bonding and barrier properties, lower formulation viscosity, and enhanced cure rates.

title: Terabyte Disk Drive
abstract: The data storage requirements for many DOD and commercial applications are rapidly surpassing the current technology in disk storage capabilities. For the DOD, there is a substantial increase in the amount of data coming from new and refined sensors, and many command centers are being required to go moblie, exacerbating the data storage problems. For commercial applications, multimedia applications with itnegrate voice and video are becoming widespread but are swamping current disk storage technology. What is needed is a new form of data storage disk drive that is small, inexpensive, capable of storing 100 billion to a trillion bytes or more, suitable for mobile applications, and capable of being read, written and rewrittent at a high data rate. By exploiting and extending our unique technology and capability for manufacturing and marketing ultra high density, analog optical memory chips, we propose: Phase I - provide and semonstrate by simulation, a modular engineering design concept for writing, rewriting and reading data onto/from the disk, along with fabrication details of the disk and system design; Phase II - fabricate the device designed in Phase I.

title: Human Systems/Subsystems Research
abstract: On-Board Oxygen Generation Systems (OBOGS) are currently monitored using oxygen sensors of the electrochemical variety.  These sensors are subject to degradation with storage or use, and therefore require periodic recalibration or replacement.  The newer zirconia sensors furthermore operate at 750C, generally require a reference gas, and do not measure oxygen at 100% concentration reliably.  It is desirable to monitor to 100%, O2 cylinder gas, which is used at high altitude and as a back-up supply in case of OBOGS failure. Oxigraf proposes to use laser diode absorption spectroscopy in the visible spectrum to monitor oxygen concentration.  The Oxigraf sensor in development for the past five years measures oxygen concentration in medical environments from 5 to 100% with +- 0.2% accuracy with fast 0.1 second response.  This sensor can be perfected in Phase I to measure at aircraft altitude and be insensitive to vibration.  In Phase II, the mean time between maintenance of the sensor can be extended from 1,000 to perhaps 15,000 hours using available improved laser diodes.  In addition, aircraft packaging, electronic interfacing, and thermal, vibration, and other environmental testing can be achieved.  In Phase III< Normalair-Garrett of Yeovil, England, an established supplier of aircraft oxygen systems, is prepared to pursue adoption on military aircraft systems provided the technology is perfected as proposed. A letter of support is attached on page 23 of this proposal.

title: Hyper-spectral Imaging for Target Detection in Deep Clutter
abstract: It has been shown that targets buried in deep clutter such as camouflaged tanks and missile launchers can be identified using spectral band correlation techniques.  The narrower the spectral band the more accurate the correlation statistics.  What is needed to identify manmade objects buried in deep cluttered backgrounds is an instrument with the capability of tunable multi-spectral image data collection with bandwidth selection and coverage that spans the spectral region from visible to the thermal infrared.  The Pacific Advanced Technology Image Multi-spectral Sensor, (IMSS), has the capability to fulfill the Navy's requirements for an adaptive multi- spectral imaging sensor which can be flown on an airborne platform for deep hide target detection.  This proposed program will culminate in a multi-spectral sensor that will be ready to integrate into a the Navy's P3 surveillance aircraft. The technical objective of the Phase I effort is to prove feasibility for a conceptual design for a Phase II hardware multi-spectral imaging instrument development effort.  Another objective is to secure a Phase II partner willing to financially support the Phase II effort in matching funds.  This will allow Pacific Advanced Technology to qualify for the 'fast track program".

title: Simulation of Optical Environmental Effects
abstract: PSR proposes to design, develop and demonstrate the feasibility of a novel hardware-in-the-loop technique for simulating the effects of the atmosphere on the performance of Navy optical systems. The simulator will use computer controlled, non-random optical elements that can readily interface in modular fashion with Navy sensors. It will permit assessing the combined effects of molecules, aerosols and turbulence on system performance. The simulator will be well calibrated, repeatable, and permit variation with the environmental parameters that drive the atmospheric components that induce the degradations, as well as operational parameters such as range and line of sight variations during an engagement. Both spatial amplitude (scintillation and fading) and spatial phase (distortion, wander) effects of turbulence will be simulated with the PSR programmable system.

title: Fiber Optic Coupled Infrared Focal Plane Array (FOCIRFPA)
abstract: PSR proposes to design an image relay system for mid-infrared (2 - 4.8 micron) sensors. Novel diffractive faceplates coupled with a coherent fiber optic bundle will allow a mid-infrared (MIR) focal plane array (FPA) sensor to be located 10 meters from the objective lens. The feasibility study will consider reimaging optics to match the image field with the fiber bundle and the MIR FPA. The FPA aspect and size will be addressed, as will techniques to improve the throughput of the coherent fiber bundle. Proprietary techniques to reduce the signature of the sensor are also proposed. Fiber materials, relay optics and diffractive optics (DO) elements will be reviewed, and commercial components will be used where possible. Past PSR experience with MIR coherent fiber bundles will be useful in this application.

title: Data Parallel Programming Environment
abstract: We propose a comprehensive data parallel programming environment for High Performance Fortran and Data Parallel C. The programming environment will contain program development, compilation, debugging, and performance tool sets. The tools will be integrated to use common user interfaces within the programming environment and to work with each other seamlessly. The tools will allow programmers to debug and analyze performance of data parallel programs running in distributed memory systems. ANTICIPATED BENEFITS: The data parallel programming environment will make it easier to use scalable high-performance computers. This will help both government and commercial sites that have large computing requirements. The tools developed in this project will have significant commercial potential with users of distributed memory parallel systems.

title: On-Focal Plane Processing Techniques for Infrared Detector
abstract: Pacific-Sierra Research Corporation (PSR) and team member Santa Barbara Focalplane will develop a design for a reconfigurable HgCdTe detector array assembly which is compatible with a current Navy inventory optical scanner.  This new detector array will include on-focal plane signal processing that will result in a detector that can electronically reconfigure pixels so as to provide either an increase in sensitivity or an increase in resolution as compared to existing infrared sensor systems.  The technical approach is to utilize a two-dimensional array of small detector elements that can emulate a variety of focal plane patterns.  Detector element activation is software controlled to permit real-time manipulation of detector array geometries. It is assumed that the initial baseline technology will utilize HgCdTe and operate over the LWIR waveband.

title: LONGWAVE ELECTROMAGNETIC SENSOR FOR COUNTERPROLIFERATION ACTIVITIES
abstract: We propose to design a compact, multiple purpose electromagnetic sensor for monitoring the extremely low frequency (ELF), very low frequency (VLF), and low frequency (LF) spectrum.  Our goal is to design a modular, low cost sensor capable of being configured for multiple applications and capable of being employed in remote, unattended sensor networks.  We describe three applications or scenarios that form the basis for a requirements-driven sensor design.  These scenarios involve the need for sensors to detect, monitor, and characterize underground facilities capable of producing or testing weapons of mass destruction.  Technical objectives are to identify sets of application-specific sensor performance characteristics and to incorporate these characteristics into a flexible design.  The three function areas of antenna design, noise reduction techniques, and signal processing hold the key to sensor operation at different frequencies and with different signal extraction requirements.  Our modular design will maximize the functions in common modules and thereby minimize the changes necessary for different applications.

title: Computer Aided Engineering for Aero-Optics
abstract: PSR proposes to develop a software package for   Computer-Aided-Engineering (CAE) of laser installation aboard   aircraft.  For a selected aircraft installation site, this package   will provide a prediction of laser performance as a function of   flight conditions, pointing angle, system dynamics and   atmospherics.  It is proposed to limit the aero-optic effects to   the aircraft-generated turbulence in the region occupied by the   engine exhaust gases and the wake vortices.  The algorithms and   software will be designed to operate conveniently and with   reasonable run-time on a high-end PC (486/66 DX Intel chip or   Pentium chip) or workstations such as SUN's SPARC 10 series.  To   this end, the algorithm employed for both laser propagation and   Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) will be heuristically tailored   to the significant regimes identified during the current USAF   program on Turbulence Interactions (TI).  In addition, the   propagation and turbulence data collected during the TI program   will be provided as an accessible database for future use.  This   CAE package would be designed for system engineering applications   of interest to the Air Force.  Phase I:  Design and develop a   detailed preliminary design specification for the Aero-optics CAE.

title: Effects of Optical Scattering on Tactical Decision Making
abstract: PSR proposes to design and develop an end-to-end validated   computer model for simulating the potential performance   degradation of a pilot/vehicle operator as a result of increased   glare produced by an external low power laser or other source of   illumination.  The model will cascade modules that respectively   incorporate the  1) target/object of intended pilot observation,   2) the laser/source of external illumination, 3) atmospheric   propagation from each of these sources to the platform, 4)   propagation through the canopy or windshield, 5) from the inner   surface of the canopy to the operator's eyeball, 6) the eyeball   itself, and finally, 7) a tactical decision module.  The model will   permit performance evaluation and sensitivity studies associated   with the variation of the relevant independent parameters   associated with each module.  The model will be validated by   laboratory measurements of a simulated engagement using an   argon-ion laser and canopy.

title: Portable Infrared Measurement System
Miniature Environmental Air Sampler Using Aerogel for Biological Material Collection and Fluid Reduction
HIGH PERFORMANCE CRYOGENIC INJECTORS FOR PULSE DETONATION ROCKET ENGINES
PREEXISTING CORROSION NUMERICAL MODELING FATIGUE CRACK NUCLEATION STRUCTURAL INTEGRITY
Parameter Identification for Highly Dynamic Aircraft Maneuvers
abstract: This project will yield a new software program for parameter identification of dynamic systems using experimental test data. The primary application will be the identification of aerodynamic models governing the motion of aircraft during highly dynamic maneuvers.  One innovation of this project is the use of a time- varying nonlinear dynamic model to represent the aerodynamics of the aircraft as opposed to the traditional method using static functions.  The other innovation in this work is that the software package will be bundled with a multimedia reference application. The multimedia reference application will be written like a digital textbook about aircraft parameter identification methods and will include text, graphics, simulations, and animation of aircraft motion.  It will allow engineers and students to learn about aircraft parameter identification while using the software program to solve research and development problems.

title: Calibratable Staring FPA IR Imager
abstract: The performance of modern missile seekers is beginning to surpass that of available infrared measurement instrumentation.  Current generation measurement instrumentation was developed to calibrate single pixel or Sprite scanning imagers.  With the advent of affordable and reliable two-dimensional focal plane arrays, available for both the MiddleWave InFraRed (MWIR) and LongWave InFraRed (LWIR) regions, modern weapon systems have demonstrated improved performance and demand measurement instrumentation with sufficient fidelity and resolution to accurately characterize their performance.  A calibratable IR sensor developed around the high photon-collecting efficiency of staring FPAs is the solution to this problem.  An innovative solution to this problem is presented in this proposal which provides dual-band coverage in a compact single sensor.  An all-reflective telescope is incorporated to provide excellent stray light reduction and eliminate concerns with optics self-emissions.

title: Soft X-Ray Collimating Optics
abstract: Parallax Research Inc. proposes to develop practical collimating optics for soft x-ray lasers and elemental analyses applications. Although there is no new physics involved in the operation of these optics, the ability to fabricate them economically is a recent innovation. These optics are intended to accept broad energy bandwidths of low energy x-rays diverging from a small source and re-direct them into a well collimated beam or to focus them to a small spot. Used with laboratory x-ray lasers they would collimate the poorly collimated radiation emerging from the linear x-ray laser plasma sources. When used for x-ray elemental analyses applications for the determination of elements with Z less than A1, they would revolutionize the use of wavelength dispersive spectroscopy in Scanning and Transmission (SEM and TEM) Electron Microscopy by increasing the sensitivity of detection of these elements and decreasing data collection times. If these optics were used in conjunction with energy dispersive spectroscopy, they would enable the use of smaller detectors resulting in better energy resolution and better SNR. In this phase I program, we propose to produce the prototype of a collimator which we will sell to OEM and aftermarket suppliers of elemental analyses equipment for SEM and TAM systems. Our optics will have applications in x-ray laser research, imaging fusion plasmas, x-ray microscopy, and crystallography. We have a real market to make optics for SEM/TEM systems in which we expect to be able to sell over 100 optics/yr.

title: In-Situ Phosphorus Injection Synthesis for Single Crystal Growth of Semiconducting and Electro-Optic Phosphides
abstract: Phosphides are growing in importance in the area of semiconductor, photo-voltaic, solar energy, microwave and optoelectronic devices.  Indium phosphide is a well known semiconductor with application as a laser diode in fiberoptic communication and as a substrate for MMIC and MAFET devices for ultrahigh speed communication, computing and integrated electro-optics. InP also displays the photorefractive effect which can be utilized for infrared optical signal processing. For solar power applications, III-V's have a potential for over 30% efficiency. Parke Mathematical Laboratories, Inc. proposes to develop a novel method for high pressure synthesis of metal phosphides that has the potential to reduce the cost of III-V and II-IV-V2 materials by combining direct synthesis from highly purified elements with crystal growth from the melt executed in contiguous steps without opening the furnace. The proposed method, in contrast to in-situ techniques currently under development, will be more easily controlled, exhibit greater reproducibility, yield stoichiometric melts necessary for successful crystal growth, readily scaled, and will be much less subject to catastrophic failure. Successful development and implementation of the proposed concepts will result in a process that will eliminate the complex, multi-step feed synthesis method that is the current industry standard. Reduced manufacturing costs should be reflected in a lower product cost and wider utilization of single crystal phosphide materials.

title: Rugged Recess Drive System for Flathead Threaded Fasteners
abstract: One hundred degree flathead recess machine screws used to secure aircraft panels suffer unacceptable failure rates during removal for maintenance and repair activities.  We propose an innovative recess drive system, including the fastener recess and mating tool bit, which greatly increases removal torque capability and reduces the probability and severity of damage during fastener removal. Generous tool/recess clearance allows easy tool insertion and is tolerant of paint and dirt in the recess.  The Phase I effort includes FEM stress analysis, geometric optimization, prototype fabrication and test, and documentation.  The Phase I program objective is to demonstrate torque capability and damage resistance with prototype recess and tool hardware.

title: Intelligent Heat Flow Control for (Cd,Zn)Te Crystal Growth
abstract: Improvement in the quality, size and cost of cadmium zinc telluride, (Cd,Zn)Te, substrates is necessary in order to realize the high performance benefits of HgCdTe based infrared devices. To meet this need we propose an innovative feedback control strategy for vertical Bridgman (VB) crystal growth. Using a computational heat flow model we will formulate a control algorithm that will be coupled with a novel means for manipulating the heat flow during crystal growth. The problem area we are addressing is the ability to actively control the crystal/melt interface shape in the VB configuration to maintain a flat or slightly convex (with respect to the liquid) profile. By doing so, it will be possible to grow crystals with larger diameters and lower defect densities since the potential for stacking faults, twinning and stresses due to radial thermal gradients will be reduced. To achieve the goal of high quality (Cd,Zn)Te growth we have assembled a team that combines state-of-the-art heat flow modeling capabilities, crystal growth experience, and thermal hardware design expertise. Our approach implements a logical developmental process that will lead to the production of improved (Cd,Zn)Te substrates. Anticipated Benefits: There is a constant need to establish more robust manufacturing processes in several areas of IR detector production. The goals presented in this proposed research relate directly to achieving better quality substrate materials which is fundamental to improving overall IR detector producibility and reliability.

title: Low Weight Cryocooler For High Temperature Superconductor Antenna Cooling
abstract: Advanced anti-radiation missiles using large, high temperature superconducting antennas will require cryocoolers that can cool the antenna quickly with a minimum mass and volume penalty.  We will develop a mixed gas Joule-Thomson (J-T) cryocooler with the load heat exchanger integral to the antenna substrate.  The mixed gas J-T thermodynamic cycle is significantly more efficient than current single gas cycles, while retaining the simplicity of the J-T cycle.  The integral load heat exchanger minimizes thermal distortion in the antenna, reduces thermal resistance to the antenna, and maximizes the cooling delivery to the antenna.  We will prove the feasibility of the concept by (1) developing fabrication techniques for the integral load heat exchanger, (2) defining an optimized thermodynamic cycle design, (3) designing the components of the system to predict performance, mass, and volume, and (4) testing a scaled integral load heat exchanger (in the Option Phase).  In Phase II we will fabricate and test a prototype of the cryocooler system, including the mixed gas J-T refrigerator and the integral load heat exchanger.

title: Innovative Fabrication of 2D Ultrasonic Imaging Arrays
abstract: Current ultrasound images in mine warfare, biomedical imaging and non-destructive testing are limited by the use of linear transducer arrays which result in thick image "slices", errors from phase aberrations and primitive volumetric scanning capability.  Two-dimensional arrays will overcome these limitations. Two-dimensional arrays have not been manufactured because of difficulty in fabricating the small structures and low transducer element sensitivity.  The low sensitivity can be overcome by employing multi-layer structures. We propose an innovative, scaleable approach to manufacture low-cost, two-dimensional, multi-layer transducer arrays with low impedance and high sensitivity.  Our approach uses plasma-enhanced, reactive Physical Vapor Deposition (PVD) to deposit high- quality, perovskite lead-zirconate lead-titanate (PZT) films as the piezoelectric material and photolithogrpahy with PVD and an innovative, manufacturing scheme to provide the interlayer electrodes and element interconnections. In Phase I, we will demonstrate the feasibility of the approach by fabricating a two-dimensional, multi-layered array and measuring its impedance characteristics and acoustic performance. In Phase II, we will build fully populated two-dimensional, multi-layered imaging arrays and test them for element sensitivity, interelement isolation, electrical impedance and beamforming performance and use them to form three-dimensional images.

title: Compact Thermal Energy Recovery System for Intercooled Gas Turbine Incorporated
abstract: Our objective is to develop an innovative thermal management system for recovering waste heat from engines.  The proposed system will tap the large quantities of waste hat from the intercooler of gas turbine engines and use a Rankine cycle to increase the power of core gas turbine, or to drive an electric generator to power auxiliary systems.  The innovative aspect of this thermal management system is to employ Creare's advanced component technology for compact heat exchangers and high-efficiency turbomachines to minimize the size and weight of the energy recovery system.  For aerospace thermal management applications, Creare has developed very compact, high flux heat exchangers which can be used to gather heat from the intercooler as well as to boil and condense the working fluid.  Creare has also developed turbomachinery and systems for aerospace applications in which advanced fabrication techniques enable small size and high efficiency, and non-contact bearings give simplicity and high reliability.  By integrating these advanced technology components, we will develop a lightweight, small volume energy recovery system for gas turbine engines. during Phase I we will select a engine, perform sizing and design studies to develop conceptual designs, select an efficient bottoming cycle based upon our advanced component technology, and prepare a plan to test the system in Phase II.   We will develop this technology for commercial applications for various transportation systems on land, sea, and air, including passenger vehicles with internal combustion engines to improve fuel economy.

title: Low-Cost Cascade J-T Cryocooler with an Oil-Free Compressor
abstract: We propose to develop an inexpensive, high performance closed-cycle  cascade J-T cryocooler. The cryocooler will be based on a high pressure ratio,  oil-free, metal diaphragm compressor.  This innovative compressor will be  compact, inexpensive and extremely reliable. The compressor can either be  used with single-stage mixed-gas or multi-stage cascade cycles. For a  single-stage mixed gas cryocooler, the compressor will allow reduced cost and  higher reliability due to the elimination of oil cleanup systems. It will also enable  a new class of high performance low-cost cryocoolers based on the cascade  J-T cycle.  In Phase I we will design and fabricate a proof-of-concept model of this  compressor, measure its volumetric efficiency and pressure ratio, and use it to  drive a commercial mixed-gas J-T cold head. We will also show that the  compressor will be inexpensive to manufacture in volume due to its lack of  close-tolerance parts.  In Phase II, we will design and fabricate a complete two-stage cascade J-T  cryocooler.  We expect that this cooler will exhibit a mean time to failure in  excess of three years, be inexpensive to manufacture and offer efficiencies  comparable to the best small Stirling cycle cryocoolers.
agency: Office of the Secretary of Defense

title: Imaging IR System for NDE of GaAs Wafers
abstract: The performance of lasers, solar cells, and other devices   fabricated from doped GaAs wafers depends strongly on the quality   of the underlying wafer.  For best performance, the wafers must   have uniform carrier concentration and low defect density.  GaAs   wafer manufacturers and users currently do not have a rapid,   non-destructive way of measuring these parameters.  As a result,   GaAs devices remain expensive due to relatively low device yields.  We propose to develop a system to measure these properties by   measuring the wafer transmissibility at selected wavelengths in the   IR.  The proposed imaging IR system will allow rapid, accurate,   high-resolution and inexpensive measurement of wafer electrical   properties.  In Phase I, Creare will prove the feasibility of the   method by developing proof-of-concept hardware and software and   comparing the NDE measurements with results from conventional   destructive techniques.  In Phase II, we will automate the system   and make it clean-room compatible.

title: Micromachined Substrates with Thin-Film Base to Improve Power Density in Alkali Metal Systems
An Advanced Distillation Oxygen System for Aircraft Oxygen Supply Systems
Field Level Repair/Joining of Composite Aircraft Structure Using Ultrasonic Methods
Development of a High Throughput Version of the Moving Probe Tester
Continuous Intersecting Structures for Stiffened Frames and Bulkheads
Space Qualifiable, Corrosion Resistant, Near Hermetic Plastic Package
High Temperature Braided Composite Preforming for Advanced Turbine Engine Components
Production of Custom Fit Oxygen Masks Using Rapid Prototyping Technology

agency: Office of the Secretary of Defense

title: Fast Dynafoil Sealift Ship
abstract: The combination of high speed (100-200 knots) and long range (10,000 miles) required for a modern sealift ship requires a lift/drag (L/D) ratio greater than 32.  Only a hydrofoil craft can achieve this (i.e. L/D greater than 40 for the foil alone). A recent surface proximity hydrofoil theory suggests (in contrast to the traditional theory) that large span foil with a conventional sub-cavitating foil section can reach these speeds without cavitating.  Our proposed Phase I includes experiments which will resolve this question.  If it turns out that the new surface proximity theory is incorrect, it is still theoretically possible to achieve the required performance with the "planning foils" (atmospherically vented upper surface and hence no possibility of cavitation) which we are developing.  The ride of conventional hydrofoil would be intolerably rough in a seaway at 100-200 knots.  We have been developing a foil suspension system during the last several years which avoids this and other problems, using a four ton "Dynafoil" prototype boat.  We propose to design a second a second prototype during Phase I which, built early in Phase II, will serve as a demonstrator for the technologies critical to a full size sealift ship.  Since two independent investors have already contributed nearly one million dollars to this program, it's anticipated that Phase II could be co-sponsored under the new DoD Fast Track procedure.

title: Modeling of CMP Equipment and the Impact on Dielectric Thickness Variation
abstract: Chemical-mechanical polishing (CMP) is an emerging process technology that planarizes the dielectric in multi-layer interconnect structures during integrated circuit (IC) fabrication.  CMP is an important technology to support multilayer interconnect.  Since the results of CMP is dependent on the topography of the chip, systematic spatial variations due to layout pattern dependencies are, today, unavoidable.  Since CMP variation dominate interconnect dielectric variation, these systematic spatial dependence can have a significant impact on speed variations and potential race conditions.  By leveraging from existing research at MIT, as well as PDF's background in TCAD frameworks and statistical modeling, we propose to determine the requirements software and engineering methods which couple CMP equipment, chip and feature level simulation.  The eventual goal is to provide an environment for predicting the variations in interconnect capacitance as a function of CMP equipment settings.  Such a system would help defray the costs of applying CMP to low volume products.  This project will have widespread impact on CMP tool and sensor improvement; process design, optimization and control; and integrated circuit design for manufacturability.  Development of software which makes CMP techniques more affordable and reliable is of great interest to most commercial and military manufacturers.  Moreover, only physically-based simulation will render CMP viable for low-volume applications such as those common in the defense community.

title: Enhancing the Accuracy and Utility of Performance Measurement in the AF
abstract: Final course grades in military technical schools are frequently used as the criterion in assessing the validity of a variety of cognitive, perceptual, and psychomotor ability tests.  PDRI proposes an innovative approach to criterion development for use by AF researchers.  During the proposed Phase I SBIR effort, we plan to begin development of two sets of criterion measures.  The first set will be designed to link predictor scores directly to their training or job performance analog, thus providing evidence for construct validity using an external construct validation strategy. A second set of technical proficiency performance measures will be constructed and presented in a computerized adaptive rating format, which will help raters to provide more precise, accurate criterion performance scores.  Workshops will be held with subject matter experts to review predictor constructs, target possible analog performance measures for both the training and job settings, and generate critical incidents of effective and ineffective performance.  Our Phase I efforts will conclude with the development and presentation of a demonstration of the new computerized adaptive rating scale technology.

title: Measurement of Stress Adaptability
Thermal Management for Controls and Accessories on Advanced Gas Turbine Engines
abstract: The elimination of the lubrication and hydraulic systems for the advanced IHPTET engines and their replacement with magnetic bearing systems and electrically driven accessories using an internally mounted starter/generator will challenge the engine designer to define thermal management systems for these electrical components. The buried nature of the starter/generator and the magnetic bearing systems makes these components difficult to cool.  It is desired to arrive at a single thermal management system for the components. Drawings of a control/accessory subsystem along with the thermal management system will be completed as part of this contract.  In addition a simplified one dimensional math model that describes the control and accessory component bulk temperatures will be derived and supplied.
